How to find a Kepler planet with lightkurve¶

This tutorial describes the basics tasks that are often necessary in order to find planet transits in the Kepler data. More precisely, this tutorial makes use of Kepler-10 data, a G-type star which is 564 light years away from Earth. Kepler-10 is known to have at least two orbiting planets. In this tutorial, we will start from the pixel data down to the lightcurve data, in order to find the first planet, Kepler-10b.

First, let’s load some standard scientific Python packages.

In [1]:

%matplotlib inline
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

Then, let’s load some functionalities from our favorite open source package for Kepler data analysis:

In [2]:

from lightkurve import KeplerTargetPixelFile, box_period_search

Note: If you want to know details about the KeplerTargetPixelFile class, please see the target pixel file tutorial. In short, a KeplerTargetPixelFile takes a path (local or URL) and creates an object which has properties and methods about a target pixel file such as flux, header, etc.

In [3]:

tpf = KeplerTargetPixelFile("https://archive.stsci.edu/missions/kepler/target_pixel_files/"
                            "0119/011904151/kplr011904151-2009350155506_lpd-targ.fits.gz")

Let’s use the plot method and pass along an aperture mask and a few plotting arguments.

In [4]:

tpf.plot(aperture_mask=tpf.pipeline_mask, scale='log', cmap='gray')

Out[4]:

<matplotlib.axes._subplots.AxesSubplot at 0x10da92080>

Now, we will use the to_lightcurve method to create a simple aperture photometry lightcurve using the mask defined by the pipeline which is stored in tpf.pipeline_mask.

In [5]:

lc = tpf.to_lightcurve(aperture_mask=tpf.pipeline_mask)

Let’s take a look at the output lightcurve.

In [6]:

plt.figure(figsize=(17, 4))
plt.plot(lc.time, lc.flux, 'ko', markersize=3)
plt.plot(lc.time, lc.flux, 'o', color='pink', markersize=2)
plt.ylabel(r"Flux $(e^{-}s^{-1})$")
plt.xlabel(r"Time - 2454833 (days)")

Out[6]:

Text(0.5,0,'Time - 2454833 (days)')

Now let’s use the flatten method, which applies a Savitzky-Golay filter, to remove long-term variability that we are not interested in.

In [7]:

flat, trend = lc.flatten(return_trend=True)

Let’s plot the trend estimated by the Savitzky-Golay filter:

In [8]:

plt.figure(figsize=(17, 4))
plt.plot(lc.time, lc.flux, 'ko', markersize=3)
plt.plot(lc.time, lc.flux, 'o', color='pink', markersize=2)
plt.plot(trend.time, trend.flux, color='#00035b')

Out[8]:

[<matplotlib.lines.Line2D at 0x1c1aebd400>]

and the flat lightcurve:

In [9]:

plt.figure(figsize=(17, 4))
plt.plot(flat.time, flat.flux, 'ko', markersize=3)
plt.plot(flat.time, flat.flux, 'o', color='pink', markersize=2)

Out[9]:

[<matplotlib.lines.Line2D at 0x1c1ae20be0>]

Now, let’s run a period search function similiar to the Box-Least Squares algorithm (http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2002A%26A…391..369K):

In [10]:

prob, periods, best_period = box_period_search(flat, min_period=0.1, max_period=5,
                                               nperiods=750, period_scale='log')

  0%|          | 0/750 [00:00<?, ?it/s]/Users/jvmirca/anaconda3/lib/python3.6/site-packages/scipy/optimize/optimize.py:1850: RuntimeWarning: invalid value encountered in double_scalars
  tmp2 = (x - v) * (fx - fw)
/Users/jvmirca/anaconda3/lib/python3.6/site-packages/scipy/optimize/optimize.py:1851: RuntimeWarning: invalid value encountered in double_scalars
  p = (x - v) * tmp2 - (x - w) * tmp1
100%|██████████| 750/750 [02:12<00:00,  5.65it/s]

In [11]:

plt.plot(periods, prob)
plt.ylabel("log posterior + constant")
plt.xlabel("Period (days)")

Out[11]:

Text(0.5,0,'Period (days)')

In [12]:

best_period # correct period: 0.837495

Out[12]:

0.83792535000369317

Now, let’s use the fold method passing along the best_period:

In [13]:

fold = flat.fold(period=best_period)

In [14]:

plt.figure(figsize=(17, 4))
plt.plot(fold.time, fold.flux, 'ko', markersize=3)
plt.plot(fold.time, fold.flux, 'o', color='pink', markersize=2)

Out[14]:

[<matplotlib.lines.Line2D at 0x10e0235f8>]

And we can clearly see the transits of Kepler-10b.
